revisions.*:
'''Freddie Brooks''' (born 1962) is an [[United States|American]] [[singer-songwriter]] and [[blues]] [[harmonica]] player. A native of [[Wichita, Kansas]], he started performing on the [[Southern California]] blues scene in 1989.<ref> {{cite news | first = Mike | last = Boehm | title = Album Review; The Word on 'One Little Word' | date = 15 September 1999 | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/45424232.html?dids=45424232:45424232&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+15%2C+1999&author=MIKE+BOEHM&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Album+Review%3B+The+Word+on+%27One+Little+Word%27%3A+Great%3B+****+THE+FREDDIE+BROOKS+BAND+%22One+Little+Word%22+KingAce&pqatl=google | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | accessdate = 2011-04-08}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | title = FORMER KANSAN MAKES SPLASH IN CALIFORNIA FREDDIE BROOKS IS A RISING STAR IN THE SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA BLUES SCENE | date = 14 November 1999 | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WE&s_site=kansas&p_multi=WE&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB576BDA4A37B9C&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | work = [[Wichita Eagle]] | accessdate = 2011-04-08}}</ref>  He played [[West Coast blues]].

==Biography==
Brooks began playing in Southern California in 1989.<ref name=boehm1999>{{cite news|last=Boehm|first=Mike|title=The Word on 'One Little Word|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/45424232.html?dids=45424232:45424232&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Sep+15%2C+1999&author=MIKE+BOEHM&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Album+Review%3B+The+Word+on+'One+Little+Word'%3A+Great%3B+****+THE+FREDDIE+BROOKS+BAND+%22One+Little+Word%22+KingAce&pqatl=google|accessdate=8 April 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=15 September 1999}}</ref>   He played with Bernie Pearl in a few bands before releasing his first and only album, ''One Little Word'' in 1999.<ref name=boehm1999 />  Brooks was a regular performer in [[Orange County, California]].<ref name=lat6Jan2000>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Randy|title=The Orange County Contenders|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/jan/06/entertainment/ca-51360|accessdate=8 April 2011|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=6 January 2000}}</ref> 

Brooks also played with [[Jim Belushi]].<ref name=ocweekly>{{cite news|title=The 129 Greatest OC Bands Ever: 90 - 129|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/2003-06-26/features/the-129-greatest-oc-bands-ever-90-129/4/|accessdate=8 April 2011|newspaper=[[OC Weekly]]|date=19 June 2003}}</ref> 

A 2003 article in ''[[OC Weekly]]'' noted that Brooks retired from music.<ref name=ocweekly />

==Reception==
Randy Lewis of The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' praised Brooks' 1999 album ''One Little Word'', complimenting the range of emotions of the songs.<ref name=lat6Jan2000 /> Mike Boehm, also of the ''Los Angeles Time''s, noted Brooks' versatility on the album, and compared his backing band to [[Booker T. & the MGs]] backing [[Otis Redding]].<ref name=boehm1999 />  The ''OC Weekly'' ranked Brooks as #111 in the greatest Orange County bands of all time, calling ''One Little Word'' one of the best albums of the decade, citing its originality and energy.<ref name=ocweekly />   

==Discography==
*''One Little Word'' (1999)
